Rational design and precise fabrication of advanced functional materials are intimately linked to the technological advances in synthetic methodologies. The high-temperature shock (HTS) method, which involves an ultrafast heating/cooling rate (>105 K s–1) and features kinetics-dominated characteristics in material synthesis, exhibits high superiority in exploring and controllable preparation of novel materials that are typically unobtainable, such as high-entropy composition, thermodynamically metastable phases, and defect-rich surfaces. Among these significant advances, high-entropy alloy (HEA) nanoparticles are particularly prominent in heterogeneous catalytic reactions with remarkable activity, selectivity, and stability owing to their flexible composition space and high-entropy mixing structure. In this review, the physicochemical principles of HTS are presented, and the equipment and mechanisms of representative HTS techniques (e.g., Joule heating, laser heating, microwave heating) are comprehensively introduced, with the aim of accelerating the development of burgeoning HTS techniques. The concept and features of HEAs are also briefly introduced, and recent progress in the synthesis of HEAs using the HTS techniques is reviewed to provide a focused view on the unique advantages of HTS synthesis for HEAs and the exploration of novel materials. Finally, conclusions and perspectives are also provided for future investigations of HTS and HEAs, which have great significance in guiding their development and integrating their strengths. Graphical Abstract The characteristics of high-temperature shock (HTS) are matched with those of the fabrication of catalytic high-entropy alloys (HEAs). We present the physicochemical principles of HTS, introduce three typical methods (Joule heating, laser heating, and microwave heating), and review the progress of HEAs prepared by HTS. Keywords High-temperature shock Joule heating Laser heating Microwave heating High-entropy alloy Nanomaterial Catalysis reaction 1 Introduction The development of materials science is inextricably linked to the development of synthetic chemistry, and the precise control of thermodynamic and kinetic parameters allows the design and preparation of advanced functional materials for various practical applications [1,2]. Traditional high-temperature fabrication processes (e.g., using electric furnaces) can be approximately regarded as near-equilibrium and thermodynamically dominated thermal-treatment processes owing to the low heating and cooling rates (0–1 K s–1) (Fig. 1(a) ) [3,4]. Consequently, the products obtained via traditional near-equilibrium heating methods are typically thermodynamic products with the lowest total free energy and most stable atomic arrangement (bottom of Fig. 1(b)). To overcome these thermodynamic limitations and explore novel materials, it is necessary to develop rapid synthetic methods in which kinetics dominates the preparation or processing of materials [5–7]. In general, there are two strategies for constructing nonequilibrium high-temperature conditions to achieve kinetically dominated processes. One is constructing transient high-temperature conditions in the timescale of seconds or even sub-seconds (e.g., the electricity-triggered high-temperature shock), and the other is by quickly passing the precursor through a constant high-temperature region (e.g., the fast-moving bed method). High-temperature shock (HTS) synthesis is a burgeoning technology based on the former that can achieve an ultrafast heating/cooling rate of ~105 K s–1 and a peak temperature greater than ~3000 K within a time scale of seconds or milliseconds (Fig. 1(c)) [8–11]. As shown at the top of Fig. 1(b), kinetic products obtained via HTS feature free-energy local minima and are thermodynamically metastable. Typical HTS techniques include electricity-triggered Joule heating, electromagnetic-wave-triggered laser heating, and microwave heating. As shown in Fig. 1(d), Joule heating and laser heating have been developed for more than one century, but are only recently employed in the function-oriented preparation of nanoparticles (NPs) [8]. By virtue of these intriguing and powerful synthetic methods, a highly diverse library of kinetically dominated materials with ultrasmall sizes [12–15], metastable phases [16–19], defect-rich surfaces [20–22], and high-entropy compositions [23–29] have been obtained. Among the significant advances achieved by transient high-temperature synthesis, high-entropy alloys (HEAs) important owing to their huge multi-element composition space, unique high-entropy mixing structure, and excellent performance in various applications [32]. Because of their four well-known core effects, HEAs are recognized as desirable catalyst candidates with excellent activity, selectivity, and stability during multistep tandem reactions, and HEAs have thereby attracted extensive attention. Since 2004, a numerous reports on HEAs have been published, particularly in the last five years (Fig. 2(a) ). The basic mechanism of catalysis is the conversion of molecules or intermediates at active sites; therefore, the number and species of active sites determine the catalytic performance (Fig. 2(b)). The main physical parameters of HEAs used in catalytic applications are their size and composition, which can be used to compare the advantages and disadvantages of various synthesis methods. A finer size leads to a larger specific surface area, providing numerous active sites, whereas a multi-element composition offers a variety of adsorption sites, both of which are essential for a catalyst. However, bulk HEAs with low surface areas and limited number of catalytically active sites considerably hinder their application in catalysis [24,33]. However, the rapid quenching rate of HTS can efficiently inhibit phase segregation and the coarsening of HEA nanoparticles (HEA-NPs); the obtained HEA-NPs with large numbers of diverse active sites can be used for catalytic applications (Fig. 2(c) [34–37]. Although there are several studies and reviews based on HTS, including catalysts, graphene/supercapacitors [38–40], and batteries [41–43], the physicochemical fundamentals of HTS from the energy–space–time perspective have not been explored intrinsically. In this review, we focused on the fundamental physicochemical basis and features of HTS techniques. The experimental setup, mechanisms, advantages, and disadvantages of Joule heating, laser heating, and microwave heating are systematically summarized and analyzed. Subsequently, as a model material system, the development and deployment of HEA-NPs in heterogeneous catalysis are highlighted. Furthermore, challenges and corresponding strategies for developing high-performance HEA nanocatalysts are proposed. High-entropy nano-catalysts prepared by HTS beyond HEAs are also briefly reviewed. Finally, perspectives on the future development of HTS and HEAs are outlined. 2 Mechanism of high-temperature shock synthesis In traditional physicochemical processes, only energy and time parameters are considered, and the energy transformation follows the law of conservation of energy, as shown in the following equation: (1) E input = P·t = E absorb + E dissipate where E input can be regarded as any form of input energy, such as electricity, laser, and microwave, P is the power of the energy source, and t is the time of the energy input duration. E absorb represents the energy absorbed by the material, in which the absorbed energy is finally converted into heat energy, and E dissipate is the dissipated energy that does not participate in the heating process. A coefficient relationship exists between E absorb and E input as shown in Eq. (2), in which the absorption coefficient is defined as ξ. E absorb is finally converted into heat energy; therefore, a functional relationship also exists between the heat energy and intrinsic parameters of the material, as shown in Eq. (3). (2) E absorb = ξ·E input = ξ·Pt = Q (3) Q = cm(ΔT) ξ is interrelated with the features of materials, reaction environment, and heating approaches; Q represents the heat energy and is numerically equal to E absorb; c and m denote the specific heat capacity and mass of materials, respectively. ΔT is the temperature difference between the initial and final conditions. Combining Eqs. (2) and (3) yields Eq. (4). (4) ξ·P/cm = ΔT/t where ΔT/t represents the heating rate, which is related to the reaction environment, heating approaches (ξ), power (P) of the input energy source, and natural features (c, m) of the materials. In addition, because of the effects of input energy on the target, reaction volume (V) is a crucial parameter. Therefore, when the natural features of a material are excluded, the heating rate is the coupling of energy (E), space (V), and time (t). As shown in Fig. 3(a) , I, II, and III represent the energy density (E/V), power (E/t), and an isolated system without an energy input (V/t), respectively. At the center, the energy-space-time coupling region represents the power density (E/(t·V)), which dominates the heating rate of HTS. The stronger the energy input, the smaller the space and shorter the time duration, which implies a greater power density with a greater absorption coefficient, thereby generating an ultrafast heating rate. The energy-space-time characteristics of four heating methods, including Joule heating, laser heating, microwave heating, and near-equilibrium heating are shown in Fig. 3(b). In addition, the heating rate and space of devices in the heating methods are illustrated in Fig. 3(c). As the additional energy supply is removed during the cooling process, the cooling rate is dominated by the natural properties of the materials and heat dissipation. The dissipated heat per unit time can be described as follows. (5) Q = κ·S(ΔT) where κ and S represent the thermal conductivity and area of the material, respectively. Therefore, materials with a high κ are preferred to obtain a high cooling rate. Moreover, maximum heat should be dissipated in the form of thermal radiation [37]. In summary, factors such as the thermal radiation coefficient, thermal conductivity, size, and specific heat capacity should be comprehensively considered for the selection of heated substrates, to achieve rapid temperature variation. Currently, carbon-based materials with satisfactory thermal radiation coefficients and thermal conductivities are generally employed [47–50]. In addition, the material, shape and size of the substrate, pressure, atmosphere, voltage, and current in the HTS process can affect the reproducibility, and should be carefully and rigorously controlled. 2.1 Joule heating mechanism Joule heating is an ultrafast and emerging synthetic technology based on Joule’s law, which was discovered by the British physicist Joule in 1841. The mathematical expression for Joule’s law is as follows. (6) Q = I 2 Rt where I is the current flowing through the substrate, R is the resistance of the substrate, and t is the electrification time. According to the Ohm’s law for partial circuits (I = U/R), the input voltage, current, resistance of the substrate, and electrification time can be regulated by the reaction parameters. Compared with traditional near-equilibrium heating approaches, Joule heating directly affects the targets supported on the substrate, which leads to lesser dissipation and an improved utilization rate of heat. In other words, Joule heating has higher ξ. In addition, the instantaneous power density and ultrafast heating/cooling rate of Joule heating are considerably higher compared with those of typical heating approaches. A schematic of the Joule heating system is shown in Fig. 4(a) and 4(b). The substrate is hooked to two copper electrodes in the desired atmosphere, and electrodes are connected to a direct current power supply. A digital camera is used to capture macroscopic images through a glass window during the reaction process, and a spectrometer is combined with an optical fiber for temperature estimation [8,9]. The temperature can be altered by regulating the voltage and current of the power supply. Moreover, as previously mentioned, the gas environment and parameters (e.g., type, shape, and size) of the substrate are also related to temperature. Joule heating can be divided into four stages as shown in Fig. 4(b) [32]. First, the precursors are attached to the substrate without energy input. Second, the substrate is connected to the power supply, and the current passes through the substrate; collisions among electrons, and between electrons and substrate molecules occur at the microscale, and the conversion of kinetic energy into heat energy results in the decomposition of the precursor. Third, the mixing of metal atoms, nucleation, and crystal growth occur sequentially. Finally, the power-off-triggered ultrafast quenching generates uniformly dispersed ultrafine nanomaterials. 2.2 Laser heating mechanism Compared with Joule heating, laser heating can provide a higher energy density, which leads to ultrafast heating and quenching rates of up to 109–1012 K s–1 [55–57]. However, it causes certain damage to the sample because of the considerably high energy density, thereby the productivity is lower [58–60]. A schematic of the laser heating setup is shown in Fig. 4(c) [51]. The fiber laser is coupled and controlled by a computer, and the laser beam passes through a focusing lens and affects the target material. This setup is equipped with an additional antechamber and a separate pneumatic vibrating system to provide the desired gas atmosphere. The reaction conditions is varied by tuning the parameters, including wavelength, duration, energy, and spot area. The microcosmic mechanism of laser heating is based on the photothermal effect, which is an extension of the photon hypothesis proposed by Einstein in 1905 [61–63]. A typical application of laser heating based on carbonaceous supports is shown in Fig. 4(d) [52], in which the pulse energy is precisely delivered to the supports and generates a plasma plume containing electron jet flow. The metal ions are then reduced under high-temperature conditions. Finally, the reduced metal atoms diffuse and aggregate along the carbonaceous supports and instantaneously cool into ultrafine nanoalloys. Moreover, according to the Stark-Einstein law, every atom is activated accompanied by the absorption of energy equivalent to that of one photon. The energy of a photon is expressed as follows: (7) ε = hν = hc/λ where h is the Planck constant, ν is the optical frequency, and c and λ are the speed of light and wavelength, respectively. Because red light has the longest wavelength, which corresponds to the minimum ??. Further, maximum number of atoms are excited when the input energy is constant (E = constant = n·??; n is the number of photons and corresponds to that of activated atoms), which leads to a significant photothermal effect. 2.3 Microwave heating mechanism Microwaves are electromagnetic waves with frequencies ranging from 300 MHz to 300 GHz, and the corresponding wavelengths are 1 m–1 mm. Decimeter (300 MHz to 3 GHz), centimeter (3 GHz to 30 GHz), and millimeter (30 GHz to 300 GHz) waves are all microwaves [64]. Fig. 4(e) shows the schematic of the setup for microwave heating. It mainly consists of a microwave cavity, a solid-state microwave generator (~2.45 GHz generally) coupled with a control system, an infrared pyrometer employed to evaluate temperature, a gas flow connected to the sample chamber, and a microwave measuring instrument [53]. The precursors are placed in the sample chamber filled with the required gas, and the maximum temperature reaches approximately 103 K when microwave energy is employed [65–68]. Fig. 4(f) shows the schematic for the microcosmic mechanism of microwave heating [54]. There are two accredited mechanisms for microwave heating: ionic conduction and dipole rotation [69–71]. In the ionic conduction mechanism, the ions oscillate repeatedly by the microwave electromagnetic field. During this process, the ions collide with each other and the kinetic energy is eventually converted to heat energy (left in Fig. 4(f)). In the dipole rotation mechanism, the orientation of the dipole tends to coincide with the magnetic field, and as a result, the dipole rotates and is accompanied by molecular friction and dielectric loss, which transform into heat energy (right in Fig. 4(f)). Microwave heating has satisfactory productivity and flexible operability, and can be integrated with other methods (e.g., ball milling, Joule heating, and laser heating) at low costs. However, absorbers are required to provide high temperatures, which complicates the process and limits its application [58,64]. The characteristics of the different heating methods are summarized in Table 1 . In other words, Joule heating, laser heating, and microwave heating possess their own unique features and strengths; all of them can provide a considerably higher energy density and faster heating/cooling rate than those of traditional near-equilibrium methods (Fig. 5 ). 2.4 Catalytic superiority of high-temperature shock synthesis Instantaneous high temperature and ultra-fast cooling rate are generated owing to the high power density of HTS; therefore, HTS performs differently from traditional synthesis in defect engineering, crystal phase engineering, heterojunction structure, and elemental miscibility. Furthermore, catalysts prepared by HTS can appropriately balance the catalytic activity and stability compared to traditional methods. (1) HTS can induce and effectively maintain defects (for example, rich dislocation and strain [20,22], twin boundaries [19], stacking faults [47], and vacancies [15]), thereby regulating the electronic structure of adsorption sites and improving the interaction between adsorption intermediates and adsorption sites, thereby enhancing the performance. (2) HTS can induce a large number of heterointerfaces, which provide abundant active sites with moderate adsorption free energy, and the strong chemical bonding between the catalysts and carriers significantly enhances mechanical stability owing to the instantaneous high temperature [16]. (3) HTS provides a high energy density in an extremely short pulse followed by ultrafast cooling, which induces the conversion of stable phases into their respective metastable phases due to the overcoming of the formation energy difference between the two phases. Some metastable phases exhibit excellent performance in specific catalytic reactions [17]. (4) HTS can break through the confinement of elemental combinations in solid solutions, allowing the formation of alloys with immiscible elements in a single phase owing to the ultrafast quenching rate, which is important for enriching catalytic sites and developing new compositional catalysts, especially multi-element high-entropy alloys [72,73]. 3 High-temperature shock synthesis of HEAs HTS has been widely used for the synthesis of HEAs owing to its high peak temperature and rapid heating/cooling rates. HEAs are based on the concept of multi-principal alloys proposed by Yeh [75] in 2004, which is considered to be one of the three breakthroughs in alloying theory in recent decades (the other two are bulk metallic glasses by Inoue and gum metals by Saito) [76]. There are two accepted definitions for HEAs. One is based on components, in which alloys contain at least five dominant elements with atomic percentages between 5% and 35%. The second is based on mixing entropy (ΔS mix) and is given by the following Eq. (8) [77–80]. (8) Δ S m i x = Δ S m i x c o n f + Δ S m i x v i b + Δ S m i x m a g + Δ S m i x e l e c where Δ S m i x c o n f , Δ S m i x v i b , Δ S m i x m a g , and Δ S m i x e l e c represent the configurational, vibrational, magnetic dipole, and electronic randomness entropies, respectively. In solid-solution HEAs, Δ S m i x c o n f is dominant in ΔS mix [81] and can be calculated as follows: (9) Δ S m i x c o n f = k ⋅ ln W = R ( 1 N ln N + 1 N ln N + ⋯ + 1 N ln N ) = R ln N where k, W, R, and N represent the Boltzmann constant, confusion degree, molar gas constant, and number of near-equimolar ratio elements, respectively. When ΔS mix < 1R, the alloys are defined as low-entropy alloys (LEAs). As shown in Fig. 6(b) , most conventional alloys belong to this category. However, when 1R ≤ ΔS mix ≤ 1.5R and ΔS mix ≥ 1.5R, the alloys are defined as medium-entropy alloys (MEAs) and HEAs, respectively (Fig. 6(a)) [82–85]. There are four core effects in HEAs (Fig. 6(c)). (1) The high-entropy effect in thermodynamics refers to the enhanced Δ S m i x c o n f of HEAs compared with pure metals and intermetallic compounds. According to Eq. (9), the Δ S m i x c o n f increases as N increases, and the increased Δ S m i x c o n f favors the formation of solid solutions rather than the ordered or intermetallic phases in multi-component alloys [86–89]. According to the Computer Coupling of Phase Diagrams and Thermochemistry (CALPHAD) and experimental results, the most common microstructures of HEAs possess several phases that range from one to a number less than the average CALPHAD results (close to the maximum number allowed by the Gibbs phase rule), which supports the high entropy effect [74,83]. (2) The lattice distortion effect in the structure refers to the severe lattice distortions that are generated in HEAs because of the different sizes and properties (e.g., bonding energy and crystal structure tendency) of various metal atoms, which leads to alterations in the electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity, and related electronic structures [90,91]. (3) In the sluggish diffusion effect, the potential energy varies considerably at different lattice locations because of the lattice distortion effect, resulting in an increased activation energy for atomic diffusion. The increased activation energy impedes the diffusion of atoms; therefore, the diffusion rate of HEAs is lower than that observed in conventional alloys. Furthermore, the considerable high-temperature phase stability of HEAs is associated with the sluggish diffusion effect [92–96]. (4) Cocktail effects are observed in performance, as proposed by Ranganathan [97,98]. As a result of the diverse properties of multiple elements and their interactions, HEAs exhibit composite effects with outstanding and comprehensive performance compared to those of any individual element [99,100]. These four core effects endow HEAs with unique advantages in catalytic reactions. Owing to the high entropy effect, HEAs are equipped with high compositional tunability, which leads to the regulation of electronic and geometric structures, resulting in the excellent catalytic performance of HEAs [108,113–117]. In terms of energy, HEA-NPs are not the most thermodynamically stable structures; for example, they undergo phase separation during slow annealing [23]. However, in terms of applications, HEA-NPs have good chemical and structural stabilities owing to the lattice distortion and sluggish diffusion effects. In addition, the arrangement of a large number of atoms on the HEA surface can provide various surface sites to adsorb, activate, and convert the reactants or intermediates, which also boosts the catalytic activity [88,118–120]. Therefore, HEAs have attracted increasing attention for various catalytic reactions such as the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [36,101–103,107,121–125], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [26–28,31,73,102–107,123,126–129], oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [25,52,108,109,127,130], methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) [108,110,131,132], carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [133–135], nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [136], NH3 decomposition/oxidation [23,137,138], and CO oxidation [111,112,123,139]. The catalytic performances of the HEAs and their derivatives are summarized in Table 2 . Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are an important approach to determine the exact active sites in various catalytic reactions and investigate the catalytic mechanisms. Through experiments and DFT calculations, Hao et al. [140] verified that in a typical FeCoNiMnRu HEA, the Co site is conducive to the dissociation of H2O, and Ru site accelerates the combination of two H* to H2 for the HER in 1 M KOH. Therefore, it is important to identify the active sites for the design of HEAs. Nellaiappan et al. [134] performed DFT calculations to gain insights into the CO2RR. Cu is the active site in the AuAgPtPdCu HEA. Compared with the Cu (111) surface, because of the destabilization of the *OCH3 intermediate and stabilization of the *O intermediate on the HEA surface, the thermodynamic properties of CO2RR on the HEA surface are better than those on the Cu (111) surface. In addition, by calculating the free-energy adsorption of CO and H, the AuAgPtPdCu HEA has been found to be selective for hydrocarbon products rather than CO and H2. Therefore, it is important to identify the active sites for the design of HEAs. The discovery of HEAs has been related to bulk amorphous alloys. Therefore, the traditional fabrication processes for HEAs can be categorized into three major routes, identical to those for amorphous alloys. The first route is from the liquid state, which is the most common technique for preparing HEAs [76], and mainly includes arc melting [33,89,92,95,141,142], vacuum inductive melting [143,144], laser melting [145], and laser enhanced net shaping (LENS) [146]. The second is a solid-state method, which includes mechanical alloying and milling [87,111,147], and spark plasma sintering [120]. The last approach is the vapor state route, which includes magnetron sputtering deposition [148,149], pulse laser deposition, atomic layer deposition, molecular beam epitaxy, and vapor phase deposition. Nonetheless, HEAs prepared using traditional methods as catalysts face two unavoidable problems. First, their dimensions are bulk, generally in micron or submicron sizes, which constrains the utilization of atoms. Moreover, the low quenching rate of conventional approaches leads to phase segregation, making it difficult to synthesize HEAs with more than eight elements [23]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop novel methods for the synthesis of HEAs. Because of their ultrafast heating/cooling rates and ultrahigh peak temperatures, HTS can provide nanoscale particles with a high degree of atomic disorder, which can effectively address these challenges in the HEA fabrication. With the development of HTS and other advanced approaches, the synthesis of HEAs on the nanoscale has become universal and simple. At present, it is possible to synthesize HEA-NPs containing up to 8–15 elements through HTS [23,24]. In addition, HEAs with up to 21 elements have been synthesized by the arc-discharge method [150]. In addition to HTS and traditional methods, other novel methods such as fast-moving bed pyrolysis [121,151], aerosol synthesis [104,152,153], and co-reduction [36,112] have emerged in recent years. The characteristics of the different synthesis methods are summarized in Table 3 . 3.1 Joule heating for HEAs Joule heating was first used in physics, and has recently been used in the ultrafast fabrication of nanomaterials. Chen et al. [8] developed a systematic synthesis strategy for nanomaterial fabrication and demonstrated the advantages of Joule heating over near-equilibrium heating methods. They presented a homemade setup for nanoscale synthesis and described a method for the extraction of temperature via the blackbody radiation equation, which has been used to conduct similar studies. Importantly, they proposed an innovative mechanism using molecular dynamics simulations in which the defects in the RGO substrate constrained nanoparticle aggregation and merging, resulting in well-dispersed nanoparticles with small sizes. Simultaneously, the particles were protected from oxidation by the RGO sheets, which addressed the two major challenges of agglomeration and surface oxidation in this approach. Finally, they demonstrated the application of Al nanoparticles-RGO as a switchable energetic material and the ubiquity of this method, providing innovative ideas for energy materials, such as batteries and catalysts. Their work provides great inspiration for the preparation of nanoparticles via non-equilibrium Joule heating. Since then, the application of Joule heating in chemical synthesis has been reported frequently in various fields, such as high-entropy nanomaterials [23–27,159], graphene [160–162], ceramics [3,154], and the selective transformation of inert chemical bonds [30]. As previously mentioned, rapid heating can be performed using thermal shock or a fast-moving bed (Fig. 7(a) ). Hu et al. [23] made a milestone achievement in the synthesis of HEA-NPs using carbothermal shock based on the Joule heating principle and fabricated nano-scale alloys with an ultrahigh reaction temperature (> 2000 K) and a fast rate of heating and cooling (105 K s–1) in only 55 ms. The underlying carbon support inhibited the coalescence and growth of the HEA-NPs. As a result, octahedral solid-solution HEA-NPs containing Pt, Pd, Ni, Co, Fe, Au, Cu, and Sn were formed with a face-centered cubic (FCC) structure. In addition, phase-segregated multi-component NPs were produced by lowering the cooling rate, which provided insights into the formation mechanism of metallic glass, HEA-NPs, and heterogeneous phase-separated structures; a mixed phase must be reached before solidification, and then preserved at an optimal cooling rate, such that phases do not separate and metallic glass is not generated. (Fig. 7(b)). Quinary HEA-NPs (PtPdRhRuCe) were synthesized as ammonia oxidation catalysts with ~100% conversion and >99% nitrogen oxide selectivity over prolonged operations (Figs. 8(a–c) ). This research suggests that Joule heating possesses enormous potential to yield novel catalysts [163]; however, it may be possible to use more advanced characterization techniques for HEAs, such as four-dimensional scanning transmission electron microscopy (4D-STEM). Another challenge is that HEAs consist of strongly repelling combinations (e.g., Au-W), and easily oxidized elements (e.g., Zr) are difficult to incorporate using the conventional approach. Consequently, Yao et al. [24] achieved a homogeneous mixing of 15 elements (15-HEA NPs) including strongly immiscible and easily oxidized combinations by entropic design (high temperature and high entropy; T×ΔS mix) using Joule heating (Fig. 7(c)), and the extreme mixing of 15 transition metals in a uniform alloy structure was characterized (Fig. 7(d)). Importantly, the authors applied 4D-STEM and a strain map to characterize the atomic properties of the HEA (Figs. 8(d) and (e)). This extreme mixing strategy of high temperature and entropy was further extended to the HEA components. Fast-moving pyrolysis is another rapid heating strategy [121,151–153,158,164,165]. Jiao et al. [158] reported a non-contact and continuous “fly-through” synthesis of Pt NPs, which is promising for ultrafast and roll-to-roll manufacturing to enable viable applications (Fig. 7(e)). Inspired by this work, Yang et al. [152] reported an aerosol droplet-mediated technique for the scalable synthesis of FeCoNiCuPt HEA-NPs with an average diameter of ∼59 nm. As shown in Fig. 7(f), an aqueous solution of metal salts was nebulized to form ∼1 μm aerosol droplets, was passed through the Joule heating device within ~3 s, and the rapid heating/quenching resulted in the decomposition of the precursors and formation of the HEA-NPs. This approach provides a facile and tractable synthesis technique that enables the scalable processing of HEAs. Song et al. [165] also synthesized FeCoNiCuPt HEA-NPs using an aerosol droplet-mediated technique and investigated the high-temperature oxidation behavior of HEA-NPs using in situ gas-cell TEM. The results suggested the preferential surface segregation of Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu under oxidizing conditions, whereas Pt remained in the core of the NPs. Combining Joule heating with advanced techniques to synthesize HEAs is a potential direction, Yao et al. [109] reported the high-throughput synthesis and screening of a series of ultrafine and alloyed multi-metallic nanoclusters by Joule heating (~2000 K, ~500 ms), as shown in Figs. 7(g) and 7(h); two promising catalysts (PtPdRhNi and PtPdFeCoNi) were discovered for the ORR by this approach. Compared with Pt/CNF, the HEA-NPs exhibited higher half-wave potentials (E 1/2) and excellent stability (Figs. 8(f–h)). The high-throughput synthesis and screening method provides a route to accelerate the compositional investigation of various HEAs, but in this study, their high-throughput characterization was poor. To the best of our knowledge, modification strategies of electrocatalysts include constructing heterojunctions and loading cocatalysts for boosting electrocatalysis, especially clusters or single atoms [166–169]. Shi et al. [102] designed highly efficient and durable catalysts using non-noble HEA-NPs to disperse and stabilize noble metal clusters (Fig. 7(i)). Pt clusters exposed on the surface of the FeCoNiCu HEA (HEA@Pt) were prepared by Joule heating and demonstrated excellent hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) performance (Figs. 8(i) and (j)). Although there are no related reports on the synthesis of high-entropy stabilized single-atom catalysts via Joule heating, based on HEA-stabilized single-atoms [111,147] and high-temperature shockwave-stabilized single-atoms [170], we believe that high-entropy stabilized single-atom catalysts will be prepared via Joule heating in the near future. 3.2 Laser heating for HEAs Laser heating is an energetic, ultrafast, and general synthesis technique with non-equilibrium features that can be applied to synthesize various high-entropy nanomaterials. In general, there are two types of objects for laser heating: liquids and solids. Zou et al. [107] synthesized a vast library of HEA-NPs and high-entropy ceramics nanoparticles (HEC-NPs) by laser scanning ablation (LSA). The corresponding NPs precursors were ablated in only 5 ns per pulse. The associated setup and process are shown in Fig. 9(a) . They explored the universality of this method and synthesized high-entropy materials, including alloys, sulfides, oxides, borides, nitrides, and phosphides, and mixed up to nine elements (PtAuPdCuCrSnFeCoNi). PtIrCuNiCr HEAs are used as electrocatalysts for overall water splitting with an exceptionally low overpotential of 185 mV at 10 mA cm–2 and exhibit excellent stability (Figs. 10(a) and (b) ). Yang et al. [31] fabricated high-entropy nanomaterials using simple pulsed laser irradiation scanning on mixed salt solutions (PLMS) (Fig. 9(b)). The catalytically active CoCrFeNiAl HECs displayed state-of-the-art activity and stability in the OER, as shown in Figs. 10(c) and (d). Importantly, they performed a systematic material characterization to investigate the complicated structures of CoCrFeNiAl HECs and confirmed the spinel structure AB2O4 (A, B = Co, Cr, Fe, Ni, or Al), in which the A and B sites can be replaced with other elements. This universal method is suitable for various metal-salt precursors and substrates. To explore the possibility of industrialization, Waag et al. [126] reported colloidal CoCrFeNiMn HEA-NPs with ultrafine sizes electrostatically stabilized in ethanol, which were synthesized by picosecond-pulsed laser heating. It should be emphasized that the scaled-up process has a yield of 3 g h–1, which provides the evidence for industrial applicability. In addition to the surrounding liquid, carbon is a common substrate for laser heating. Jiang et al. [52] reported that metal salts were directly converted into ultrafine HEA-NPs on a carbonaceous support using a nanosecond pulsed laser. As shown in Fig. 9(c), owing to the unique laser-induced thermionic emission and etching on a carbonaceous substrate, the reduced metal elements aggregate into ultrafine HEA-NPs and are stabilized by a defective carbon support. Senary PtPdRhFeCoNi HEA-NPs synthesized by this method exhibited excellent catalytic performance with an E 1/2 of around 0.85 V in ORR (Fig. 10(e)). Lu et al. [103] employed laser heating to fabricate senary FeCoNiCuPtIr HEA-NPs supported on the surface of carbon nanotubes in the timescale of hundreds of milliseconds, and the fabricated HEA-NPs exhibited remarkable bifunctional performance for both the OER and HER (Fig. 10(f)). Fig. 9(d) shows the temperature distribution, which demonstrate a ramp-up to 1600 K in 50 ms and heating and cooling rates of 46.4 and 7.4 K s–1, respectively. Furthermore, DFT calculations demonstrate that Pt atoms are the best HER sites, and Ir atoms improve the OER performance of the FeCoNiCuPtIr HEAs in water redox, as shown in Figs. 10(g) and (h), which is consistent with previous studies. Laser heating is accompanied by bright light during the heating process when carbon materials are used, which is similar to Joule heating. The HR-TEM results suggest that metallic atoms are uniformly distributed on the HEA-NPs, as shown in Fig. 9(e). Manipulating the parameters of the laser makes it possible to achieve both phase transition and distinct dimensions simultaneously, which is significant for HEAs. 3.3 Microwave heating for HEAs The application of microwave heating in chemical synthesis was first reported in 1986 for the synthesis of simple organic compounds, such as C6H5COOH and C6H5COOCH3 [172,173], and was subsequently extended to the rapid synthesis of a range of materials, for example, metal/alloy NPs [48,174–177] and single-atom catalysts [178]. Microwave heating requires microwave-absorbing materials, and carbon is an ideal material for microwave heating. Zhong et al. [171] developed a one-step general strategy for rapid surface engineering of carbon materials via microwave-induced carbothermal shock. As shown in Fig. 11(a) , the temperature of carbon fiber cloth (CC) rapidly increases to 1500 K within 5 s while emitting a bright light for 2 s to complete the surface engineering process. Furthermore, this study attempts to conduct microwave heating synthesis in a roll-to-roll process, which can be used for scaling up (Fig. 11(b)). Based on the beneficial information obtained in this study and an insightful understanding of CC with modifications, in later research, Zhong et al. [155] demonstrated an efficient and scalable microwave heating approach using carbon materials as substrates to prepare HEA-NPs. Because a large number of functional group defects can effectively absorb microwaves, reduced graphene oxide (rGO) was employed as a model substrate to generate high temperatures up to ∼1850 K within milliseconds, and the quenching rate could be as high as 6×104 K s–1, as shown in Figs. 11(c) and 11(d). Li et al. [106] synthesized a series of HEA-NPs embedded in CC via microwave heating. As shown in Figs. 12(a–f), PtRhCoNiCu/CC exhibits outstanding HER activity (170 mV at 1000 mA cm–2) and stability (more than 150 h), while IrRuCoNiCu/CC exhibits superior OER activity (354 mV at 1000 mA cm–2) and stability (more than 150 h). For overall water splitting, IrRuCoNiCu/CC(+)//PtRhCoNiCu/CC(–) electrolyzer achieves a high current density of 1000 mA cm–2 at 1.88 V and excellent stability (100 h) because of the “cocktail” and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) effects (Figs. 12(g) and (h) ). In addition to carbon materials, metal powders and metal precursors can be directly used as microwave-absorbing materials. Tang et al. [28] synthesized highly efficient porous CoCrFeNiMo-xMg HEAs (x = 0, 10, and 20) by mixing metal powders and microwave sintering. The HEAs are composed of only a single FCC crystal phase (Fig. 11(e)) and have long-term durability for the OER, with a low overpotential of 220 mV at 10 mA cm–2 (Fig. 11(f)). Wu et al. [157] synthesized quaternary single-phase multi-principal element alloys featuring high entropy in the oil phase via microwave heating. The HEAs possess a small particle size of ~6 nm (Fig. 11(g)), and the structural characterization methods, including XRD, HAADF-STEM, and EDX mapping, confirms the FCC structure and uniform distribution of all elements in the NPs (Figs. 11(h) and (i)). The oil-phase strategy is advantageous for the preparation of ultrafine NPs and matches the flexibility of microwave heating, which is important for reconsidering the environmental parameters of microwave synthesis. 4 High-temperature shock synthesis for other high-entropy materials Doping materials with nonmetal elements such as oxygen, boron, phosphorus, or sulfur can alter the electronic structures of catalysts, which is considered an effective approach for improving their properties [179–181]. Multi-element oxide nanoparticles (MEO-NPs) and high-entropy oxide nanoparticles (HEO-NPs) have been proven to improve the performance and thermal stability of catalytic reactions [112,147]. However, MEO-NPs have been largely limited to fewer elements, owing to the increased difficulty of mixing multiple elements. Li et al. [159] developed three design strategies (temperature-, oxidation-, and entropy-driven mixing) to synthesize and stabilize single-phase MEO-NPs with assorted structures (e.g., fluorite, perovskite, spinel, and rock-salt) and used them for catalysis, energy storage, and material discovery (Fig. 13(a) ). Through these strategies, they successfully synthesized 10-element MEO-NPs (10-MEO-PdO), and the materials demonstrated superior performance in catalytic methane combustion, achieving a complete CH4 conversion at 673 K (Fig. 14(a) ) and exhibiting considerably stable catalytic activity with no evident drop after the 100 h test (Fig. 14(b)). In another study [25], they prepared 10-HEO-NPs by Joule heating and achieved good stability for the ORR during long-term operations while maintaining a high activity with an E 1/2 of 0.82 V because of the SMSI between HEO-NPs and carbonous substrate (Figs. 14(c) and (d)). As shown in Fig. 13(b), the HTS synthesis of HEO-NPs can modify the structural stability and avoid NP detachment or agglomeration in conventional electrocatalysts manufactured by near-equilibrium heating. Meanwhile, the high-entropy design of HEO-NPs can enhance the chemical stability and prevent elemental segregation. Both the aforementioned researchers applied carbon materials as the heating substrate, whereas Wu et al. [73] employed nickel foil as the heating substrate, and rocksalt-HEOs, spinel-HEOs, and perovskite-HEOs were successfully synthesized through Joule heating, which provides an innovative approach. As shown in Figs. 14(e) and (f), (MnFeCoNiZn)O with a rock salt structure exhibits an outstanding OER activity (300 mV of overpotential at 10 mA cm–2) and long-term stability. Additionally, DFT simulations confirm the superior activity due to the more continuous density of states near the Fermi level and lower ΔG of the rate-determining step (Fig. 14(g)). In addition to favored HEOs, Hu et al. [154] fabricated high-entropy borides (HEBs) using carbon-based Joule heaters. Temperature is tuned at approximately 3000 °C, which is lower than that in arc-melting method but higher than that in spark plasma sintering; in other words, this method fills the temperature gap in conventional sintering approaches (Fig. 13(c)). High-entropy sulfide nanoparticles (HES-NPs) are considered potential catalysts for OERs owing to their good activity and electrical conductivity. Cui et al. [27] prepared quinary HES-NPs with a uniform size of 11.9 nm through a facile Joule pulse thermal decomposition method (Fig. 13(d) and (e)). Additionally, they synthesized binary, ternary, and quaternary sulfides using the same approach. The results of electrochemical tests indicated that quinary HES-NPs possessed remarkable OER performance (Fig. 13(f)) and DFT calculations demonstrated that Co was the active site (Fig. 13(g)). In contrast to HEAs and alloys doped with nonmetals, high-entropy metallic glass nanoparticles (HEMG-NPs) possess both high-entropy metallic character and amorphous structures, which are promising for energy conversion and catalytic reactions. Johny et al. [127] generated colloidal carbon-coated HEMG-NPs by utilizing pulsed laser ablation of bulk HEA targets in acetonitrile, and the solvent produced thin graphitic layers around the HEMG-NPs to stabilize the amorphous phase in the high-entropy system. The degree of amorphization was influenced by the addition of different Mo molar fractions in quinary CrCoFeNiMn-based HEMG-NPs, which determined the OER and ORR performances (Fig. 13(h)). Yu et al. [105] synthesized a RuNiMoCrFeO x catalyst by microwave heating for 120 s after grinding, and the HEO catalyst exhibited high performance (219 mV at 10 mA cm–2) with excellent stability (at a high current density of 100 mA cm–2 with an overpotential of 261 mV for up to 100 h) in 0.5 M H2SO4, as shown in Figs. 14(h) and (i). They proved that high entropy stabilizes the lattice oxygen of RuNiMoCrFeO x participating in the acid OER process through isotopic gas detection and electron spin resonance, which can broaden the application of high-entropy materials. 5 Conclusions and perspectives In this review, we systematically introduce HTS techniques (such as Joule heating, laser heating, and microwave heating) that feature rapid, efficient, and low cost preparation of advanced functional materials with novel morphology (e.g., ultra-small size) and crystal phase (e.g., metastable phase, defect-rich structure) characteristics compared with traditional near-equilibrium thermal treatment methods. The physicochemical principles of HTS are summarized, and the parameters involved, such as the power density and absorption coefficient, are declarative. The characteristics of HTS (such as non-equilibrium dominated by kinetics and ultrafast heating/cooling rates) are matched with the preparation of catalytic HEA-NPs; therefore, related concepts, superiorities, and applications of HEAs are also discussed. Finally, a summary of recent progress in the fabrication of HEA-NP catalysts and other high-entropy material catalysts using HTS approaches is presented. Although HTS has been widely reported in recent years, there is still enormous space to be explored. The following sections describe the future directions (Fig. 15 ). First, according to the current research trends in catalysis and surface/interface chemistry pointed out by the Chinese Expert Panel of Strategy Symposium [182], “the research process ranges from static, steady and equilibrium to dynamic, transient and non-equilibrium; the space-time has been delving into nanoscale/clusters and femtosecond/attosecond; the interdisciplinary integration is more important” and we can predict that HTS techniques will take advantage of its features to further favor research on millisecond, microsecond, and even nanosecond non-equilibrium syntheses. To achieve this purpose, it is exciting to explore new energy sources with considerable power densities, and focus on advanced materials with high thermal radiation coefficients and electrical conductivities. In the process of preparing HEAs by HTS with more advanced parameters, extremely high temperatures and ultrafast heating/cooling rates may have unexpected effects on the structure and morphology, thereby creating novel HEAs with multiple elements (≥ 8), which is an attractive direction. Second, the applications of HTS are still at the laboratory level with a per-batch productivity of milligram to gram, and industrialization is a long-term and complex process. Therefore, the development of the associated facilities is a top priority. The requirements of atmosphere, pressure, peak temperature, and heating/cooling rates inevitably involves miscellaneous reaction chambers, sensors, and precise controllers at high temperatures or pressures, which is also crucial work worth investing in. Finally, it is still difficult to determine the nucleation and crystal growth of materials synthesized by HTS at the atomic level, owing to the ultrafast synthesis process. An in-depth understanding of these mechanisms will provide positive feedback on the parameters designed for the HTS controller, which is instructive for the precise synthesis and tuning of materials. The use of HEAs as catalysts is a promising research field. The “Materials Genome Initiative” accelerates the upgrading and blossoming of basic materials, such as metallic/non-metallic materials and alloys/HEAs [85]. Therefore, it is expected that correlation studies on HEAs will become increasingly favored, and the following aspects are worth noting. First, and most importantly, the rational design of HEAs is hampered. Although there are performance volcano relationships of individual elements for reference [183], the cocktail effect of HEAs makes the composition design of HEAs more unpredictable, and the structure–activity relationship of HEAs requires further investigation. The design of HEAs for catalysis should be based on thermodynamics and dynamics, determine the composition and structure rules, and determine the active sites. Computational techniques such as density functional theory (DFT), molecular dynamics (MD), and Monte Carlo simulations can provide effective design guidance for HEAs. The composition and synthesis conditions of the HEAs are the primary factors to be considered. For example, Pt-based HEAs are more suitable for the HER, whereas Cu-based HEAs are more suitable for the CO2RR. Additionally, immiscibility and easy oxidation of elements need to be addressed, as a high-temperature- and high-entropy-based strategy (T*ΔS mix) can expand the content of HEAs [24]. In addition, special morphologies and appropriate preparation methods are worth considering aspects. Second, advanced characterization techniques, such as synchrotron X-ray-based techniques, in-situ transmission electron microscopy (in-situ TEM), four-dimensional scanning transmission electron microscopy (4D-STEM), and atomic electron tomography (AET) need to be further developed, which is crucial for a comprehensive understanding of HEAs. In addition, from the “Materials Genome Initiative,” a basic software, and databases have been developed. Based on this database, it is highly efficient to introduce machine learning (ML) tools and high-throughput screening [115,137,184,185] into the investigation of HEAs. Computational synthesis can assist in rapid access to desirable materials. It should be noticed that the preparation of HEAs through high-throughput HTS is an attractive study, and its core is the high-throughput characterization. Although a microscanning electrochemical workstation has been applied for electrocatalysis, more efficient characterization methods should be devised. In conclusion, HTS is a near-perfect approach for the synthesis of HEA-NPs. The development of HTS techniques should also be considered while focusing on the investigation of HEAs. Ren, J. Greeley, G. Wang, A. Anapolsky, L. Hu, Science, 2022, 376, eabn3103. Yanan Chen is a Professor in School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University. He received his Bachelor’s degree and joint Ph.D. degree from University of Science and Technology Beijing/University of Maryland in 2012 and 2017 respectively. He was an advanced innovative fellow at Tsinghua University before joining in Tianjin University. His research mainly focuses on nanomaterials, devices, and systems for advanced energy storage and conversion. His research interests include high-temperature shock (HTS), ultrafast nanomanufacturing, metastable high throughput synthesis, emerging energy storages Li-ion and beyond, catalysis, artificial intelligence and interdisciplinary. He has published more than 100 research papers on international famous journals, including Nat. Energy, Nat. Commun., Sci. Adv., JACS, PNAS, A dv. Mater., Mater. Today, Nano Lett., Adv. Energy Mater., ACS Nano and has been cited nearly 7000 times (including many ESI highly cited papers). Ye-Chuang Han (Innovation Laboratory for Sciences and Technologies of Energy Materials of Fujian Province, Xiamen University). Dr. Ye-Chuang Han received his B.A. degree from Nanchang Hangkong University in 2015, and his M.S. degree from University of Science and Technology of China in 2018, and his Ph.D. degree from Xiamen University in 2022. Now, he is carrying out his postdoctoral research at Innovation Laboratory for Sciences and Technologies of Energy Materials of Fujian Province (IKKEM) and Xiamen University under the supervision of Prof. Zhong-Qun Tian. His research interests mainly focus on the synthetic methodology under non-equilibrium high temperature.

coredata.dc:description: Rational design and precise fabrication of advanced functional materials are intimately linked to the technological advances in synthetic methodologies. The high-temperature shock (HTS) method, which involves an ultrafast heating/cooling rate (>105 K s–1) and features kinetics-dominated characteristics in material synthesis, exhibits high superiority in exploring and controllable preparation of novel materials that are typically unobtainable, such as high-entropy composition, thermodynamically metastable phases, and defect-rich surfaces. Among these significant advances, high-entropy alloy (HEA) nanoparticles are particularly prominent in heterogeneous catalytic reactions with remarkable activity, selectivity, and stability owing to their flexible composition space and high-entropy mixing structure. In this review, the physicochemical principles of HTS are presented, and the equipment and mechanisms of representative HTS techniques (e.g., Joule heating, laser heating, microwave heating) are comprehensively introduced, with the aim of accelerating the development of burgeoning HTS techniques. The concept and features of HEAs are also briefly introduced, and recent progress in the synthesis of HEAs using the HTS techniques is reviewed to provide a focused view on the unique advantages of HTS synthesis for HEAs and the exploration of novel materials. Finally, conclusions and perspectives are also provided for future investigations of HTS and HEAs, which have great significance in guiding their development and integrating their strengths.

coredata.dc:title: High-temperature shock synthesis of high-entropy-alloy nanoparticles for catalysis
